segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Congratulations!
segment.target: Congratulations!

segment.source: At this point, you understand the key components of a basic Universal Windows Platform (UWP) DirectX 3D game.
segment.target: At this point, you understand the key components of a basic Universal Windows Platform (UWP) DirectX 3D game.

segment.source: You can set up the framework for a game, including the view provider and rendering pipeline, and implement a basic game loop.
segment.target: You can set up the framework for a game, including the view provider and rendering pipeline, and implement a basic game loop.

segment.source: You can also create a basic user interface overlay, and incorporate sounds and controls.
segment.target: You can also create a basic user interface overlay, and incorporate sounds and controls.

segment.source: You're on your way to creating a game of your own, and here are some resources to further your knowledge of DirectX game development.
segment.target: You're on your way to creating a game of your own, and here are some resources to further your knowledge of DirectX game development.

segment.source: DirectX Graphics and Gaming
segment.target: DirectX Graphics and Gaming

segment.source: Direct3D 11 Overview
segment.target: Direct3D 11 Overview

segment.source: Direct3D 11 Reference
segment.target: Direct3D 11 Reference

segment.source: Extending the game sample: using XAML for the overlay
segment.target: Extending the game sample: using XAML for the overlay

segment.source: One alternative that we didn't discuss in depth is the use of XAML instead of Direct2D for the overlay.
segment.target: One alternative that we didn't discuss in depth is the use of XAML instead of Direct2D for the overlay.

segment.source: XAML has many benefits over Direct2D for drawing user interface elements, and the most important one is that it makes incorporating the Windows 10 look and feel into your DirectX game more convenient.
segment.target: XAML has many benefits over Direct2D for drawing user interface elements, and the most important one is that it makes incorporating the Windows 10 look and feel into your DirectX game more convenient.

segment.source: Many of the common elements, styles, and behaviors that define a UWP app are tightly integrated into the XAML model, making it far less work for a game developer to implement.
segment.target: Many of the common elements, styles, and behaviors that define a UWP app are tightly integrated into the XAML model, making it far less work for a game developer to implement.

segment.source: If your own game design has a complicated user interface, consider using XAML instead of Direct2D.
segment.target: If your own game design has a complicated user interface, consider using XAML instead of Direct2D.

segment.source: So, what is the difference between the implementation of a user interface with Direct2D, and implementing that same interface with XAML?
segment.target: So, what is the difference between the implementation of a user interface with Direct2D, and implementing that same interface with XAML?

segment.source: You define the overlay in a XAML file, \*.xaml, rather than as a collection of Direct2D primitives and DirectWrite strings manually placed and written to a Direct2D target buffer.
segment.target: You define the overlay in a XAML file, \*.xaml, rather than as a collection of Direct2D primitives and DirectWrite strings manually placed and written to a Direct2D target buffer.

segment.source: If you understand XAML, you'll find it much easier to create and configure more complicated overlays, especially if you use Visual Studio's XAML editing tools.
segment.target: If you understand XAML, you'll find it much easier to create and configure more complicated overlays, especially if you use Visual Studio's XAML editing tools.

segment.source: The user interface elements come from standardized elements that are part of the Windows Runtime XAML APIs, including Windows::UI::Xaml and Windows::UI::Xaml::Controls.
segment.target: The user interface elements come from standardized elements that are part of the Windows Runtime XAML APIs, including Windows::UI::Xaml and Windows::UI::Xaml::Controls.

segment.source: The code that handles the behavior of the XAML user interface elements is defined in a codebehind file, Main.xaml.cpp.
segment.target: The code that handles the behavior of the XAML user interface elements is defined in a codebehind file, Main.xaml.cpp.

segment.source: XAML, as a tightly integrated Windows Runtime component, naturally handles resize and view state change events, transforming the overlay accordingly, so you don't have to manually specify how to redraw the overlay's components.
segment.target: XAML, as a tightly integrated Windows Runtime component, naturally handles resize and view state change events, transforming the overlay accordingly, so you don't have to manually specify how to redraw the overlay's components.

segment.source: The swap chain is not directly attached to a Windows::UI::Core::CoreWindow object, or at least you don't have to do this.
segment.target: The swap chain is not directly attached to a Windows::UI::Core::CoreWindow object, or at least you don't have to do this.

segment.source: Instead, a DirectX app that incorporates XAML associates a swap chain when a new SwapChainBackgroundPanel object is constructed.
segment.target: Instead, a DirectX app that incorporates XAML associates a swap chain when a new SwapChainBackgroundPanel object is constructed.

segment.source: The SwapChainBackgroundPanel object is set as the Content property of the current window object created at launch by the app singleton, and the window is passed to Simple3DGame::Initialize as a CoreWindow object.
segment.target: The SwapChainBackgroundPanel object is set as the Content property of the current window object created at launch by the app singleton, and the window is passed to Simple3DGame::Initialize as a CoreWindow object.

segment.source: You declare the XAML for the SwapChainBackgroundPanel like this in Main.app.xaml file:
segment.target: You declare the XAML for the SwapChainBackgroundPanel like this in Main.app.xaml file:

segment.source: To attach the configured swap chain to the SwapChainBackgroundPanel panel instance defined by your XAML, you must obtain a pointer to the underlying native ISwapChainBackgroundPanel interface implementation and call SetSwapChain on it, passing it your configured swap chain.
segment.target: To attach the configured swap chain to the SwapChainBackgroundPanel panel instance defined by your XAML, you must obtain a pointer to the underlying native ISwapChainBackgroundPanel interface implementation and call SetSwapChain on it, passing it your configured swap chain.

segment.source: From a method derived from DirectXBase::CreateWindowSizeDependentResources specifically for DirectX/XAML interop:
segment.target: From a method derived from DirectXBase::CreateWindowSizeDependentResources specifically for DirectX/XAML interop:

segment.source: For more info about this process, see DirectX and XAML interop.
segment.target: For more info about this process, see DirectX and XAML interop.

segment.target: Here's the complete code for the codebehinds found in the XAML version of the Direct3D 11.1 shooting game sample.

segment.source: (Unlike the version of the game sample discussed in the rest of these topics, the XAML version defines its framework in the App.xaml.cpp and MainPage.xaml.cpp files, instead of DirectXApp.cpp and GameInfoOverlay.cpp, respectively.)
segment.target: (Unlike the version of the game sample discussed in the rest of these topics, the XAML version defines its framework in the App.xaml.cpp and MainPage.xaml.cpp files, instead of DirectXApp.cpp and GameInfoOverlay.cpp, respectively.)
